Relative Chow stability and optimal weights

Carl Tipler Université de Bretagne Occidentale, 6, avenue Victor Le Gorgeu, 29238 Brest Cedex 3 France carl.tipler@univ-brest.fr
Abstract.

For a polarized Kähler manifold (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L), we show the equivalence between relative balanced embeddings introduced by Mabuchi and σ𝜎\sigma-balanced embeddings introduced by Sano, answering a question of Hashimoto. We give a GIT characterization of the existence of a σ𝜎\sigma-balanced embedding, and relate the optimal weight σ𝜎\sigma to the action of Aut0​(X,L)subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) on the Chow line of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L).

1. Introduction

By definition [2], an extremal Kähler metric on a polarized Kähler manifold (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) is a critical point of the Calabi functional, which assigns to each Kähler metric in c1​(L)subscript𝑐1𝐿c_{1}(L) the L2superscript𝐿2L^{2}-norm of its scalar curvature. Constant scalar curvature Kähler metrics (cscK for short) are special examples of extremal metrics. Initially stated for cscK metrics, the Yau-Tian-Donaldson conjecture, refined by Székelyhidi [23], predicts that the existence of an extremal Kähler metric on a given polarized Kähler manifold (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) should be equivalent to a relative GIT stability notion of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L). This conjecture should be seen as an infinite dimensional Kempf-Ness correspondence.

In [4], Donaldson introduced a finite dimensional approximation to this Kempf-Ness correspondence, via quantization. Let Aut0​(X,L)subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) be the automophism group of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) modulo the ℂ∗superscriptℂ\mathbb{C}^{*}-action by rotation on the fibers of L𝐿L. If this group is discrete, cscK metrics can be approximated by a sequence of balanced metrics. Balanced metrics are particular Kähler metrics induced by projective embeddings X↪ℙ​(H​(X,Lk)∗)↪𝑋ℙ𝐻superscript𝑋superscript𝐿𝑘X\hookrightarrow\mathbb{P}(H(X,L^{k})^{*}). They appear as zeros of a finite dimensional moment map, and their existence correspond to the Chow stability of (X,Lk)𝑋superscript𝐿𝑘(X,L^{k}) [26, 12, 18, 19]. From the general theory of moment maps, balanced metrics satisfy a unicity property. As a corollary, one obtains uniqueness of a cscK metric in c1​(L)subscript𝑐1𝐿c_{1}(L) under the assumption on Aut​(X,L)Aut𝑋𝐿\mathrm{Aut}(X,L) [4]. The quantization method is a powerful tool in the study of cscK metrics [4, 5], and it is natural to extend it to the situation Aut0​(X,L)≠0subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿0\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L)\neq 0.

Generalisation of this approximation process to extremal metrics has been pioneered by Mabuchi [13, 14, 15, 16]. His approach can be understood in the framework of relative stability [23, 1], which naturally appears in GIT in the presence of non-discrete stabilizers. In the quantization setting, elements of Aut0​(X,L)subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) acting on the Chow line of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) are an obstruction to Chow stability [14, 16, 7]. This obstruction is a source of examples of cscK manifolds that are not asymptotically Chow stable [3, 17]. It is then natural to consider a stability notion relatively to a maximal torus of symmetries T⊂Aut0​(X,L)𝑇subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿T\subset\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L), so-called Chow polystability relative to T𝑇T [15, 1].

Since then, other notions of quantization of extremal metrics have been introduced. Extremal metrics can be seen as self-similar solutions to the Calabi flow. As noticed by Sano, it is also natural to consider Donaldson’s iteration process [4] as a discretisation of the Calabi flow. The notion of σ𝜎\sigma-balanced metrics, for σ∈Aut0​(X,L)𝜎subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿\sigma\in\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L), provides a quantization of extremal metrics by self-similar solutions to Donalsdon’s iteration process [20]. The σ𝜎\sigma-balanced metrics appear as zeros of a finite dimensional moment map, and can be used to recover minimization properties, unicity or splitting results for extremal metrics [21, 22]. Another point of view is given by Hashimoto, whose defined a quantization of the extremal vector field [8]. We refer to [9] for a good reference on these different notions of quantization.

In this note, we show that Mabuchi’s relatively balanced metrics and Sano’s σ𝜎\sigma-balanced metrics are equivalent, for a suitable choice of σ𝜎\sigma. In fact, for a given maximal compact torus T⊂Aut0​(X,L)𝑇subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿T\subset\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L), there is a unique σ∈Tc𝜎superscript𝑇𝑐\sigma\in T^{c} (modulo T𝑇T) allowing the existence of a σ𝜎\sigma-balanced metric. Such an automophism σ𝜎\sigma will be called an optimal weight.

Theorem 1.1.

Let (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) be a polarized compact Kähler manifold and let T⊂Aut0​(X,L)𝑇subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿T\subset\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) be a maximal compact torus. Then (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) is Chow polystable relative to T𝑇T if and only if it admits a σ𝜎\sigma-balanced embedding with σ∈Tc𝜎superscript𝑇𝑐\sigma\in T^{c} optimal weight.

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 is a brief review on Chow stability, in relation to balanced embeddings. We introduce necessary notations, definitions and results. In section 3, we define the relative Chow scheme 𝒞​ℋ​𝒪​𝒲NT​(n,d)𝒞ℋ𝒪superscriptsubscript𝒲𝑁𝑇𝑛𝑑\mathcal{CHOW}_{N}^{T}(n,d). Restricting to the smooth case, 𝒞​ℋ​𝒪​𝒲NT​(n,d)𝒞ℋ𝒪superscriptsubscript𝒲𝑁𝑇𝑛𝑑\mathcal{CHOW}_{N}^{T}(n,d) parametrizes Tcsuperscript𝑇𝑐T^{c}-invariant subvarieties of ℂ​ℙNℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N} of degree d𝑑d and dimension n𝑛n, for Tcsuperscript𝑇𝑐T^{c} a given subtorus of Aut​(ℂ​ℙN)Autℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁\mathrm{Aut}(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N}). It provides the natural framework for relative Chow stability. We then prove Theorem 1.1 in Section 4. Along the way, we explain how an optimal weight σ𝜎\sigma twists the torus of symmetries T𝑇T to another torus Tσsuperscript𝑇𝜎T^{\sigma} so that the Chow line of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) becomes Tσsuperscript𝑇𝜎T^{\sigma}-invariant. Finally, we give a closed formula relating the optimal weight σ𝜎\sigma to the T𝑇T-character acting on the Chow line of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) in Section 4.3.

2.1. Chow stability

The idea behind Chow points and schemes is to replace the embedded submanifold X𝐬subscript𝑋𝐬X_{\bf s} by a hypersurface in a higher dimensional projective space. Consider n+1𝑛1n+1 copies of the dual projective space ℂ​ℙN⁣∗×…×ℂ​ℙN⁣∗ℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁…ℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N*}\times\ldots\times\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N*} and the divisor:

DX𝐬:={(H0,⋯,Hn)∈ℂ​ℙN⁣∗×…×ℂ​ℙN⁣∗|H0∩…∩Hn∩X𝐬≠∅}.assignsubscript𝐷subscript𝑋𝐬conditional-setsubscript𝐻0⋯subscript𝐻𝑛ℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁…ℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁subscript𝐻0…subscript𝐻𝑛subscript𝑋𝐬D_{X_{\bf s}}:=\{(H_{0},\cdots,H_{n})\in\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N*}\times\ldots\times\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N*}\>|\>H_{0}\cap\ldots\cap H_{n}\cap X_{\bf s}\neq\emptyset\}.

Set

W:=(Symd​(ℂN+1))⊗n+1.assign𝑊superscriptsuperscriptSym𝑑superscriptℂ𝑁1tensor-productabsent𝑛1W:=(\mathrm{Sym}^{d}(\mathbb{C}^{N+1}))^{\otimes n+1}.

The divisor DX𝐬subscript𝐷subscript𝑋𝐬D_{X_{\bf s}} is defined by an element Chow^​(X𝐬)^Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬\widehat{\mathrm{Chow}}(X_{\bf s}) in W𝑊W, up to a constant. The corresponding point Chow​(X𝐬)∈ℙ​(W)Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬ℙ𝑊\mathrm{Chow}(X_{\bf s})\in\mathbb{P}(W) is called the Chow point of X𝐬subscript𝑋𝐬X_{\bf s}. A remarkable fact is that X𝐬subscript𝑋𝐬X_{\bf s} is entirely characterized by Chow​(X𝐬)Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬\mathrm{Chow}(X_{\bf s}). Set d=∫Xc1n​(L)𝑑subscript𝑋superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝑛𝐿d=\int_{X}c_{1}^{n}(L) the degree of X𝐬subscript𝑋𝐬X_{\bf s} in ℂ​ℙNℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N}. 𝒞​ℋ​𝒪​𝒲ℙN​(n,d):={Y↪ℂ​ℙN|dim(Y)=n,degree​(Y)=d}.assign𝒞ℋ𝒪subscript𝒲superscriptℙ𝑁𝑛𝑑conditional-set↪𝑌ℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁formulae-sequencedimension𝑌𝑛degree𝑌𝑑\mathcal{CHOW}_{\mathbb{P}^{N}}(n,d):=\{Y\hookrightarrow\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N}\>|\>\dim(Y)=n,\>\mathrm{degree}(Y)=d\}.

We then have an injective map:

(2) Chow:𝒞​ℋ​𝒪​𝒲ℙN​(n,d)→ℙ​(W)(Y↪ℂ​ℙN)↦Chow​(Y).:Chowabsent𝒞ℋ𝒪subscript𝒲superscriptℙ𝑁𝑛𝑑→ℙ𝑊missing-subexpression↪𝑌ℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁maps-toChow𝑌\begin{array}[]{cccc}\mathrm{Chow}:&\mathcal{CHOW}_{\mathbb{P}^{N}}(n,d)&\to&\mathbb{P}(W)\\ &(Y\hookrightarrow\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N})&\mapsto&\mathrm{Chow}(Y).\end{array}

and the Chow scheme 𝒞​ℋ​𝒪​𝒲N​(n,d)𝒞ℋ𝒪subscript𝒲𝑁𝑛𝑑\mathcal{CHOW}_{N}(n,d) is by definition the image of the ChowChow\mathrm{Chow} map:

Remark 2.1.

In this paper, we restrict ourselves to smooth subvarieties of ℂ​ℙNℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N}. For moduli considerations, one may consider subschemes as well.

The SLN+1​(ℂ)subscriptSL𝑁1ℂ\mathrm{SL}_{N+1}(\mathbb{C})-action on ℂN+1superscriptℂ𝑁1\mathbb{C}^{N+1} induces an action on W𝑊W, and we are interested in the GIT quotient of the Chow scheme under this action. To simplify notation, set Gc=SLN+1​(ℂ)superscript𝐺𝑐subscriptSL𝑁1ℂG^{c}=\mathrm{SL}_{N+1}(\mathbb{C}). We will restrict ourselves to a single Gcsuperscript𝐺𝑐G^{c}-orbit:

𝒵:=Gc⋅Chow​(X𝐬)assign𝒵⋅superscript𝐺𝑐Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬\mathcal{Z}:=G^{c}\cdot\mathrm{Chow}(X_{\bf s})

Recall the definition:

Definition 2.2.

The polarized manifold (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) is Chow polystable if the Gcsuperscript𝐺𝑐G^{c}-orbit of Chow^​(X𝐬)^Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬\widehat{\mathrm{Chow}}(X_{\bf s}) is closed in W𝑊W for any 𝐬∈ℬ​(V)𝐬ℬ𝑉{\bf s}\in\mathcal{B}(V).

Note that this definition is independent on the choice of 𝐬∈ℬ​(V)𝐬ℬ𝑉{\bf s}\in\mathcal{B}(V), as seen below. We can assume, up to replacing L𝐿L by a high tensor power, that Aut0​(X,L)subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) acts on L𝐿L and thus on V𝑉V (see e.g. [10]). We then consider the induced group representation

ρ:Aut0​(X,L)→SL​(V).:𝜌→subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿SL𝑉\rho:\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L)\to\mathrm{SL}(V).

The natural right action of Gcsuperscript𝐺𝑐G^{c} on ℬ​(V)ℬ𝑉\mathcal{B}(V) commutes with the left action of ℂ∗×Aut0​(X)superscriptℂsubscriptAut0𝑋\mathbb{C}^{*}\times\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X) on ℬ​(V)ℬ𝑉\mathcal{B}(V), where ℂ∗superscriptℂ\mathbb{C}^{*} acts by scalar multiplication. The space 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} is then identified with the quotient space

𝒵≃ℬ​(V)/(ℂ∗×Aut0​(X))similar-to-or-equals𝒵ℬ𝑉superscriptℂsubscriptAut0𝑋\mathcal{Z}\simeq\mathcal{B}(V)/(\mathbb{C}^{*}\times\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X))

via the ChowChow\mathrm{Chow} map. The bundle 𝒪ℙ​(W)​(1)subscript𝒪ℙ𝑊1\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{P}(W)}(1) restricts to an ample line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} on 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} and (𝒵,ℒ)𝒵ℒ(\mathcal{Z},\mathcal{L}) is a smooth polarized Kähler manifold. In the next section, we recall the moment map condition for Chow polystability.

2.2. Balanced embeddings

We briefly recall the symplectic aspects related to Chow stability. For more details and proofs we refer to [26, 12, 18, 19]. Denote by G=SU​(N+1)𝐺SU𝑁1G=\mathrm{SU}(N+1) the compact form of Gcsuperscript𝐺𝑐G^{c}. The line bundle ℒℒ\mathcal{L} carries a hermitian metric hℎh, called Chow metric, whose curvature ΩΩ\Omega is a G𝐺G-invariant Kähler form on 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} and such that the G𝐺G-action on (𝒵,Ω)𝒵Ω(\mathcal{Z},\Omega) is hamiltonian. Denote by 𝔤=Lie​(G)𝔤Lie𝐺\mathfrak{g}=\mathrm{Lie}(G) the Lie algebra of G𝐺G, identified to its dual with the invariant non-degenerate pairing

<ξ,η>=trace​(ξ⋅η∗).formulae-sequenceabsent𝜉𝜂trace⋅𝜉superscript𝜂<\xi,\eta>=\mathrm{trace}(\xi\cdot\eta^{*}).

Denote also by m0subscript𝑚0m_{0} the moment map for the G𝐺G-action on (ℂ​ℙN,ωF​S)ℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁subscript𝜔𝐹𝑆(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N},\omega_{FS}):

where the subscript 00 stands for the trace-free part. Then the moment map μ0subscript𝜇0\mu_{0} for the G𝐺G-action on (𝒵,Ω𝒵)𝒵subscriptΩ𝒵(\mathcal{Z},\Omega_{\mathcal{Z}}) reads:

Definition 2.3.

A zero of μ0subscript𝜇0\mu_{0} is called a balanced embedding.

From [26, 12], the associated GIT notion is Chow polystability:

Theorem 2.4.

The manifold (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) is Chow polystable if and only if it admits a balanced embedding.

If Aut0​(X,L)subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L) is not discrete, there is a caracter on its Lie algebra whose vanishing is a necessary condition to Chow polystability of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L). To introduce this character, we first express the Gcsuperscript𝐺𝑐G^{c}-action on ℒℒ\mathcal{L} by mean of the moment map. For any ξ∈𝔤c𝜉superscript𝔤𝑐\xi\in\mathfrak{g}^{c}, denote by Xξsubscript𝑋𝜉X_{\xi} the infinitesimal action of ξ𝜉\xi on 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}. Then the lift of Xξsubscript𝑋𝜉X_{\xi} is given by

(5) Xξ^=Xξh+2​π<μ0,ξ>X1,formulae-sequence^subscript𝑋𝜉subscriptsuperscript𝑋ℎ𝜉2𝜋subscript𝜇0𝜉subscript𝑋1\widehat{X_{\xi}}=X^{h}_{\xi}+2\pi<\mu_{0},\xi>X_{1},

where Xξhsubscriptsuperscript𝑋ℎ𝜉X^{h}_{\xi} is the horizontal lift with respect to the Chern connection of (ℒ,h)ℒℎ(\mathcal{L},h) and where X1subscript𝑋1X_{1} denotes the vector field generating the U​(1)𝑈1U(1) action on the fibers of (ℒ,h)ℒℎ(\mathcal{L},h). Let 𝐬∈𝒵𝐬𝒵{\bf s}\in\mathcal{Z}, G𝐬subscript𝐺𝐬G_{\bf s} be its stabiliser in G𝐺G and 𝔤𝐬=Lie​(G𝐬)subscript𝔤𝐬Liesubscript𝐺𝐬\mathfrak{g}_{\bf s}=\mathrm{Lie}(G_{\bf s}). Define the map ℱℱ\mathcal{F}:

(6) ℱ:𝔤𝐬c→ℂξ↦<μ0(𝐬),ξ>.\begin{array}[]{cccc}\mathcal{F}:&\mathfrak{g}_{\bf s}^{c}&\to&\mathbb{C}\\ &\xi&\mapsto&<\mu_{0}({\bf s}),\xi>.\end{array}

We refer to [25] for a proof of the folowing:

Proposition 2.5.

For any ξ∈𝔤𝐬𝜉subscript𝔤𝐬\xi\in\mathfrak{g}_{\bf s}, the function

Gc∋g↦<μ0(g⋅𝐬),Adgξ>G^{c}\ni g\mapsto<\mu_{0}(g\cdot{\bf s}),\mathrm{Ad}_{g}\xi>

is constant. Moreover ℱℱ\mathcal{F} defines a character on 𝔤𝐬c≃Lie​(Aut0​(X,L))similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝔤𝐬𝑐LiesubscriptAut0𝑋𝐿\mathfrak{g}_{\bf s}^{c}\simeq\mathrm{Lie}(\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L)).

Remark 2.6.

The character ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is a quantization of the celebrated Futaki character [6].

By definition, the existence of a balanced embedding imposes the vanishing of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. For any ξ∈𝔤𝐬𝜉subscript𝔤𝐬\xi\in\mathfrak{g}_{\bf s}, Xξsubscript𝑋𝜉X_{\xi} and its lift Xξhsuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝜉ℎX_{\xi}^{h} vanish at 𝐬𝐬{\bf s}. However, if <μ0(𝐬),ξ><\mu_{0}({\bf s}),\xi> is not zero, the orbit of a lift x∈ℒ𝐬𝑥subscriptℒ𝐬x\in\mathcal{L}_{\bf s} under the G𝐬csuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝐬𝑐G_{\bf s}^{c}-action will contain zero, and the Gcsuperscript𝐺𝑐G^{c}-orbit will not be closed. To overcome this issue, following Székelyhidi [23], one considers a relative notion of stability. In the next section, we introduce a relative Chow scheme and the associated notion of stability.

3. Relative Chow stability

In the following, we will restrict ourselves to embedded submanifolds of ℂ​ℙNℂsuperscriptℙ𝑁\mathbb{C}\mathbb{P}^{N} that are invariant under a specified torus of symmetries.

3.1. Relative embeddings

Fix a maximal torus T𝑇T in Aut0​(X,L)subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L), and denote its complexification Tcsuperscript𝑇𝑐T^{c}. Recall that we have a representation

ρ:Aut0​(X,L)→SL​(V).:𝜌→subscriptAut0𝑋𝐿SL𝑉\rho:\mathrm{Aut}_{0}(X,L)\to\mathrm{SL}(V).

3.2. Relative stability

We come back to the symplectic picture initiated in Section 2.2, following the abstract setting of [23]. The obstruction (6) motivates the following: instead of looking for zeros of μ0subscript𝜇0\mu_{0}, try to minimize the function

Gc∋g↦‖μ0​(g⋅𝐬)‖2.containssuperscript𝐺𝑐𝑔maps-tosuperscriptnormsubscript𝜇0⋅𝑔𝐬2G^{c}\ni g\mapsto||\mu_{0}(g\cdot{\bf s})||^{2}.

A critical point for the square norm of the moment map satisfies the Euler-Lagrange condition μ0​(𝐬)∈𝔤𝐬subscript𝜇0𝐬subscript𝔤𝐬\mu_{0}({\bf s})\in\mathfrak{g}_{\bf s}. Equivalently, μ0​(𝐬)subscript𝜇0𝐬\mu_{0}({\bf s}) is equal to its orthogonal projection on the stabiliser of 𝐬𝐬{\bf s}. To have a common stabiliser for any 𝐬𝐬{\bf s}, we consider T𝑇T a maximal compact subtorus of G𝐬subscript𝐺𝐬G_{\bf s} as in Section 3.1, and restrict ourselves to the GTcsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑇𝑐G_{T}^{c} orbit of 𝐬𝐬{\bf s}:

𝒵T:=GTc⋅𝐬.assignsuperscript𝒵𝑇⋅superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑇𝑐𝐬\mathcal{Z}^{T}:=G_{T}^{c}\cdot{\bf s}.

For any 𝐬∈𝒵T𝐬superscript𝒵𝑇{\bf s}\in\mathcal{Z}^{T}, the stabilizer of 𝐬𝐬{\bf s} in GTsubscript𝐺𝑇G_{T} is T𝑇T. Denote by 𝔱𝔱\mathfrak{t} the Lie algebra of T𝑇T. We introduce the extremal vector μTsubscript𝜇𝑇\mu_{T} to be the orthogonal projection of μ0​(𝐬)subscript𝜇0𝐬\mu_{0}({\bf s}) onto 𝔱𝔱\mathfrak{t}. One obtains the relative notions of balanced embeddings and Chow stability [13, 1]:

Definition 3.2.

An embedding f𝐬subscript𝑓𝐬f_{\bf s} is balanced relative to T𝑇T if μ0​(𝐬)=μTsubscript𝜇0𝐬subscript𝜇𝑇\mu_{0}({\bf s})=\mu_{T}.

Consider at the level of Lie algebras the orthogonal decompositions

𝔤T=𝔱⊕𝔤T⟂​ and ​𝔤Tc=𝔱c⊕𝔤T⟂c.subscript𝔤𝑇direct-sum𝔱subscript𝔤superscript𝑇perpendicular-to and superscriptsubscript𝔤𝑇𝑐direct-sumsuperscript𝔱𝑐superscriptsubscript𝔤superscript𝑇perpendicular-to𝑐\mathfrak{g}_{T}=\mathfrak{t}\oplus\mathfrak{g}_{T^{\perp}}\>\textrm{ and }\>\mathfrak{g}_{T}^{c}=\mathfrak{t}^{c}\oplus\mathfrak{g}_{T^{\perp}}^{c}.

Denote by GT⟂subscript𝐺superscript𝑇perpendicular-toG_{T^{\perp}} and GT⟂csuperscriptsubscript𝐺superscript𝑇perpendicular-to𝑐G_{T^{\perp}}^{c} the connected Lie subgroups of Gcsuperscript𝐺𝑐G^{c} associated to 𝔤T⟂subscript𝔤superscript𝑇perpendicular-to\mathfrak{g}_{T^{\perp}} and 𝔤T⟂csuperscriptsubscript𝔤superscript𝑇perpendicular-to𝑐\mathfrak{g}_{T^{\perp}}^{c}.

Definition 3.3.

The polarized manifold (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) is Chow polystable relative to T𝑇T if the GT⟂csuperscriptsubscript𝐺superscript𝑇perpendicular-to𝑐G_{T^{\perp}}^{c}-orbit of Chow^​(X𝐬)^Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬\widehat{\mathrm{Chow}}(X_{\bf s}) is closed in W𝑊W for any 𝐬∈ℬT​(V)𝐬superscriptℬ𝑇𝑉{\bf s}\in\mathcal{B}^{T}(V).

Mabuchi proved the following theorem [13]:

Theorem 3.4.

The polarized manifold (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) is Chow polystable relative to T𝑇T if and only if it admits a balanced embedding relative to T𝑇T.

Note that the restriction to the GT⟂csuperscriptsubscript𝐺superscript𝑇perpendicular-to𝑐G_{T^{\perp}}^{c}-orbit is crucial. Indeed, as noticed in Section 3.1, and by Tcsuperscript𝑇𝑐T^{c}-equivariance, there is a unique χX∈wW​(T)subscript𝜒𝑋subscript𝑤𝑊𝑇\chi_{X}\in w_{W}(T) such that the set Chow​({X𝐬,𝐬∈ℬT​(V)})Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬𝐬superscriptℬ𝑇𝑉\mathrm{Chow}(\{X_{\bf s},\>{\bf s}\in\mathcal{B}^{T}(V)\}) lies in ℙ​(W​(χX))ℙ𝑊subscript𝜒𝑋\mathbb{P}(W(\chi_{X})). By construction, this character corresponds to the exponential of (a multiple) of the character ℱℱ\mathcal{F} defined in (6). Thus, if ℱ≠0ℱ0\mathcal{F}\neq 0, the Tcsuperscript𝑇𝑐T^{c} orbit of Chow^​(X𝐬)^Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬\widehat{\mathrm{Chow}}(X_{\bf s}) will contain zero for any 𝐬∈ℬT​(V)𝐬superscriptℬ𝑇𝑉{\bf s}\in\mathcal{B}^{T}(V) and its GTcsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑇𝑐G_{T}^{c}-orbit will not be closed.

Definition 3.5.

The destabilizing character of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) is the unique χX∈wW​(T)subscript𝜒𝑋subscript𝑤𝑊𝑇\chi_{X}\in w_{W}(T) such that Chow​(X𝐬)∈ℙ​(W​(χX))Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬ℙ𝑊subscript𝜒𝑋\mathrm{Chow}(X_{\bf s})\in\mathbb{P}(W(\chi_{X})) for any 𝐬∈𝒵T𝐬superscript𝒵𝑇{\bf s}\in\mathcal{Z}^{T}.

In the following section, we explain how σ𝜎\sigma-balanced embeddings overcome the issue caused by the destabilizing character, while being equivalent to relatively balanced embeddings.

4. GIT of σ𝜎\sigma-balanced metrics

An alternative notion of relative balanced embeddings has been introduced by Sano [20]. A σ𝜎\sigma-balanced metric is a self-similar solution to Donaldson’s dynamical system, and provides a quantization of extremal metrics [21].

4.1. Definition of σ𝜎\sigma-balanced embeddings

We refer to [22] for a detailed treatment of this section. Let σ∈Tc𝜎superscript𝑇𝑐\sigma\in T^{c}. We also denote by σ𝜎\sigma its image in GTcsubscriptsuperscript𝐺𝑐𝑇G^{c}_{T} under the representation ρ𝜌\rho. From the symplectic point of view, the idea behind σ𝜎\sigma-balanced embeddings is to twist the invariant pairing <⋅,⋅><\cdot,\cdot> by σ∈Tc𝜎superscript𝑇𝑐\sigma\in T^{c} to obtain a moment map orthogonal to the stabiliser 𝔱𝔱\mathfrak{t}. That way, the obstruction ℱℱ\mathcal{F} from (6) vanishes. Equivalently, one can twist the moment map μ0subscript𝜇0\mu_{0} and the symplectic form ΩΩ\Omega. On the space 𝒵Tsuperscript𝒵𝑇\mathcal{Z}^{T}, consider the map:

Theorem 4.3.

Let σ𝜎\sigma be an optimal weight and let 𝐬∈𝒵T𝐬superscript𝒵𝑇{\bf s}\in\mathcal{Z}^{T}. Then X𝐬subscript𝑋𝐬X_{\bf s} is balanced relatively to T𝑇T if and only if it is σ𝜎\sigma-balanced.

Proof.

The σ𝜎\sigma-balanced condition is equivalent to μ0σ=0superscriptsubscript𝜇0𝜎0\mu_{0}^{\sigma}=0, that is σ​μ​σ∗=cσ​1𝜎𝜇superscript𝜎subscript𝑐𝜎1\sigma\mu\sigma^{*}=c_{\sigma}1 for some real constant cσsubscript𝑐𝜎c_{\sigma}. By choice of optimal weight, ∀ξ∈𝔱for-all𝜉𝔱\forall\xi\in\mathfrak{t},

ℱσ(ξ)=<μσ,ξ>=<σμσ∗,ξ>=0,\mathcal{F}^{\sigma}(\xi)=<\mu^{\sigma},\xi>=<\sigma\mu\sigma^{*},\xi>=0,

where we use that ξ𝜉\xi is trace-free. Thus, 𝐬𝐬{\bf s} is σ𝜎\sigma-balanced if and only if σ​μ​(𝐬)​σ∗∈(1⊕𝔱)𝜎𝜇𝐬superscript𝜎direct-sum1𝔱\sigma\mu({\bf s})\sigma^{*}\in(1\oplus\mathfrak{t}). From (14), this is equivalent to μ​(𝐬)∈(1⊕𝔱)𝜇𝐬direct-sum1𝔱\mu({\bf s})\in(1\oplus\mathfrak{t}), that is 𝐬𝐬{\bf s} being balanced relative to T𝑇T. ∎

As a corollary, we recover Theorem 1.1:

Corollary 4.4.

(X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) admits a σ𝜎\sigma-balanced embedding if and only if it is Chow polystable relative to T𝑇T.

We now relate the choice of optimal weight σ∈Tc𝜎superscript𝑇𝑐\sigma\in T^{c} to the relative Chow scheme. From now on, we shall assume that the restriction of the pairing <⋅,⋅><\cdot,\cdot> to 𝔱~~𝔱\tilde{\mathfrak{t}} is normalized to be rational on the kernel of the exponential map.

Lemma 4.5.

For σ𝜎\sigma an optimal weight, (𝔱σ)csuperscriptsuperscript𝔱𝜎𝑐(\mathfrak{t}^{\sigma})^{c} is the Lie algebra of an algebraic torus in G~Tcsuperscriptsubscript~𝐺𝑇𝑐\widetilde{G}_{T}^{c}.

Proof.

It is clear that 𝔱σsuperscript𝔱𝜎\mathfrak{t}^{\sigma} is an abelian Lie algebra, and generates a compact analytic subgroup of G~Tsubscript~𝐺𝑇\widetilde{G}_{T}. Remains to show that it generates an algebraic group. The projection of μ𝜇\mu to 𝔱~~𝔱\tilde{\mathfrak{t}} doesn’t depend on 𝐬𝐬{\bf s}, and equals c​1+μT𝑐1subscript𝜇𝑇c1+\mu_{T} for a constant c𝑐c. But then σ−1​cσ​1​(σ−1)∗=c​1+μTsuperscript𝜎1subscript𝑐𝜎1superscriptsuperscript𝜎1𝑐1subscript𝜇𝑇\sigma^{-1}c_{\sigma}1(\sigma^{-1})^{*}=c1+\mu_{T} (see proof of Theorem 4.3), so that σ−1​cσ​1​(σ−1)∗superscript𝜎1subscript𝑐𝜎1superscriptsuperscript𝜎1\sigma^{-1}c_{\sigma}1(\sigma^{-1})^{*} also generates an algebraic subgroup. We conclude that σ​(cσ−1)​1​σ∗𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑐𝜎11superscript𝜎\sigma(c_{\sigma}^{-1})1\sigma^{*} satisfies the rationality condition that ensures that 𝔱σ(=cσ−1⋅𝔱σ)annotatedsuperscript𝔱𝜎absent⋅superscriptsubscript𝑐𝜎1superscript𝔱𝜎\mathfrak{t}^{\sigma}(=c_{\sigma}^{-1}\cdot\mathfrak{t}^{\sigma}) generates an algebraic torus in G~Tcsuperscriptsubscript~𝐺𝑇𝑐\widetilde{G}_{T}^{c}. ∎

Lemma 4.6.

The character χ′superscript𝜒′\chi^{\prime} is trivial.

Proof.

As σ𝜎\sigma is an optimal weight, μ𝜇\mu is orthogonal to the Lie algebra 𝔱σsuperscript𝔱𝜎\mathfrak{t}^{\sigma}. From (5), we see that the linearisation of the action of Tσsuperscript𝑇𝜎T^{\sigma} is trivial, that is χ′=0superscript𝜒′0\chi^{\prime}=0. ∎

Theorem 4.7.

The manifold (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) admits a σ𝜎\sigma-balanced embedding if and only if the Gσcsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝜎𝑐G_{\sigma}^{c}-orbit of Chow^​(X𝐬)^Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬\widehat{\mathrm{Chow}}(X_{\bf s}) is closed for any 𝐬∈ℬT​(V)𝐬superscriptℬ𝑇𝑉{\bf s}\in\mathcal{B}^{T}(V).

The optimal weight provide a relative setting where the only destabilizing symmetry is generated by σ−1​1​(σ−1)∗superscript𝜎11superscriptsuperscript𝜎1\sigma^{-1}1(\sigma^{-1})^{*}.

4.3. Optimal weight and destabilizing character

Recall from Section 3.1 that there is a unique χX∈wW​(T)subscript𝜒𝑋subscript𝑤𝑊𝑇\chi_{X}\in w_{W}(T) such that the set Chow({X𝐬,𝐬∈ℬT(V)}\mathrm{Chow}(\{X_{\bf s},\>{\bf s}\in\mathcal{B}^{T}(V)\} lies in ℙ​(W​(χX))ℙ𝑊subscript𝜒𝑋\mathbb{P}(W(\chi_{X})). In this short section, we give the precise relation between χXsubscript𝜒𝑋\chi_{X} and optimal weight σ𝜎\sigma. For this, we will restrict our attention to the T~csuperscript~𝑇𝑐\widetilde{T}^{c} action on W𝑊W.

First notice that there is a 1−1111-1 correspondence between the weights wW​(T~)subscript𝑤𝑊~𝑇w_{W}(\widetilde{T}) of the T~csuperscript~𝑇𝑐\widetilde{T}^{c}-action and the weights of the Tcsuperscript𝑇𝑐T^{c}-action on W𝑊W given by

wW​(T)→wW​(T~)χ↦χ′:(λ,t)↦λd​(n+1)⋅χ​(t)subscript𝑤𝑊𝑇→subscript𝑤𝑊~𝑇𝜒maps-to:superscript𝜒′maps-to𝜆𝑡⋅superscript𝜆𝑑𝑛1𝜒𝑡\begin{array}[]{ccc}w_{W}(T)&\rightarrow&w_{W}(\widetilde{T})\\ \chi&\mapsto&\chi^{\prime}:(\lambda,t)\mapsto\lambda^{d(n+1)}\cdot\chi(t)\end{array}

where (λ,t)∈ℂ∗×Tc𝜆𝑡superscriptℂsuperscript𝑇𝑐(\lambda,t)\in\mathbb{C}^{*}\times T^{c}. In particular, the space W𝑊W decomposes into the same direct sum of invariant subspaces under the action of these two tori, and Chow​(X𝐬)∈ℙ​(W​(χX′))Chowsubscript𝑋𝐬ℙ𝑊superscriptsubscript𝜒𝑋′\mathrm{Chow}(X_{\bf s})\in\mathbb{P}(W(\chi_{X}^{\prime})) for any 𝐬∈ℬT​(V)𝐬superscriptℬ𝑇𝑉{\bf s}\in\mathcal{B}^{T}(V).

Let σ𝜎\sigma be an optimal weight and set

ασ:=i​σ−1⋅𝒢​(σ)​Id⋅(σ−1)∗.assignsuperscript𝛼𝜎⋅⋅𝑖superscript𝜎1𝒢𝜎Idsuperscriptsuperscript𝜎1\alpha^{\sigma}:=i\sigma^{-1}\cdot\mathcal{G}(\sigma)\mathrm{Id}\cdot(\sigma^{-1})^{*}.
Proposition 4.8.

The relation between the optimal weight σ𝜎\sigma and the destabilizing character of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) is given by

ασ=χX′.superscript𝛼𝜎subscriptsuperscript𝜒′𝑋\alpha^{\sigma}=\chi^{\prime}_{X}.
Proof.

From the proof of Lemma 4.5, ασsuperscript𝛼𝜎\alpha^{\sigma} is rationnal, and thus can be written

ασ=χσnσ,superscript𝛼𝜎superscript𝜒𝜎superscript𝑛𝜎\alpha^{\sigma}=\frac{\chi^{\sigma}}{n^{\sigma}},

for χσsuperscript𝜒𝜎\chi^{\sigma} a character in H​o​m​(T~c,ℂ∗)𝐻𝑜𝑚superscript~𝑇𝑐superscriptℂHom(\widetilde{T}^{c},\mathbb{C}^{*}) (by using derivation, we identify the characters and elements in (𝔱~c)∗superscriptsuperscript~𝔱𝑐(\tilde{\mathfrak{t}}^{c})^{*}). Let ℂσsuperscriptℂ𝜎\mathbb{C}^{\sigma} be the trivial line bundle over 𝒵Tsuperscript𝒵𝑇\mathcal{Z}^{T}, with T~csuperscript~𝑇𝑐\widetilde{T}^{c}-linearisation given by (χσ)−1superscriptsuperscript𝜒𝜎1(\chi^{\sigma})^{-1}. Recall from the discussion of Section 4.2 that ασsuperscript𝛼𝜎\alpha^{\sigma} is the orthogonal projection π𝔱~​μsubscript𝜋~𝔱𝜇\pi_{\tilde{\mathfrak{t}}}\mu of μ𝜇\mu to 𝔱~~𝔱\tilde{\mathfrak{t}}, independently on 𝐬∈𝒵T𝐬superscript𝒵𝑇{\bf s}\in\mathcal{Z}^{T}. Then by construction, the moment map for the T~csuperscript~𝑇𝑐\widetilde{T}^{c}-action on (𝒵T,ℒnσ⊗ℂσ)superscript𝒵𝑇tensor-productsuperscriptℒsuperscript𝑛𝜎superscriptℂ𝜎(\mathcal{Z}^{T},\mathcal{L}^{n^{\sigma}}\otimes\mathbb{C}^{\sigma}) is nothing but

Thus the points in 𝒵Tsuperscript𝒵𝑇\mathcal{Z}^{T} are semi-stable with respect to the T~csuperscript~𝑇𝑐\widetilde{T}^{c}-action on ℒnσ⊗ℂσtensor-productsuperscriptℒsuperscript𝑛𝜎superscriptℂ𝜎\mathcal{L}^{n^{\sigma}}\otimes\mathbb{C}^{\sigma}. This action must then be trivial. But T~csuperscript~𝑇𝑐\widetilde{T}^{c} acts on ℒnσ⊗ℂσtensor-productsuperscriptℒsuperscript𝑛𝜎superscriptℂ𝜎\mathcal{L}^{n^{\sigma}}\otimes\mathbb{C}^{\sigma} with weight

(χX′)nσ⋅(χσ)−1.⋅superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜒′𝑋superscript𝑛𝜎superscriptsuperscript𝜒𝜎1(\chi^{\prime}_{X})^{n^{\sigma}}\cdot(\chi^{\sigma})^{-1}.

We conclude that ασ=χX′superscript𝛼𝜎subscriptsuperscript𝜒′𝑋\alpha^{\sigma}=\chi^{\prime}_{X}. ∎

Remark 4.9.

Note that from Proposition 4.8, the extremal vector ασsuperscript𝛼𝜎\alpha^{\sigma} only depends on the connected component of 𝒞​ℋ​𝒪​𝒲NT​(n,d)𝒞ℋ𝒪subscriptsuperscript𝒲𝑇𝑁𝑛𝑑\mathcal{CHOW}^{T}_{N}(n,d) where the Chow line of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) lies. In particular, it is invariant under embedded T𝑇T-equivariant complex deformations of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L). Considering tensor powers Lksuperscript𝐿𝑘L^{k} of L𝐿L, and letting k𝑘k go to infinity, the extremal vectors ασksuperscript𝛼subscript𝜎𝑘\alpha^{\sigma_{k}} converge to the extremal vector field of (X,L)𝑋𝐿(X,L) with respect to T𝑇T (see [22]). One recovers the fact that the extremal vector field is invariant under polarized T𝑇T-equivariant complex deformations [11].
